Table 2 Catalyst selection by transition state affinity chromatography—An assessment Anh T. Tran Jacob T. Rapp Kenneth M. Nicholas ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Stephenson Life Sciences Research Center, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019, United States Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry Stephenson Life Sciences Research Center University of Oklahoma Norman OK 73019 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A new method for catalyst selection-optimization is introduced and evaluated, transition state affinity chromatography (TSAC), based on the relative chromatographic affinity of pre-catalysts for a supported-substrate vs. a transition state analog (TSA). The affinities of a library of Zn-imine complexes on three designer HPLC affinity columns that possess either an immobilized substrate, a transition state analog or a non-binding reference compound are compared to their catalytic activities for picolinate ester hydrolysis. For those Zn-complexes whose ligands possess a hydroxyalkyl side chain the retention times on the substrate-affinity column correlate linearly with the catalyst-substrate affinity, 1/KM, derived from the kinetics of the LZn-catalyzed hydrolysis of 4-nitrophenyl picolinate. Additionally, the kinetically determined esterolytic catalytic activities, kcat, for the hydroxyalkyl-bearing complexes also correlate with their relative chromatographic affinity on the TSA- vs Sub-affinity columns. Zinc-complexes that lack the hydroxyalkyl arm, however, show no correlation of their chromatographic behavior with 1/KM and an inverse correlation with kcat. These results are interpreted in terms of differences in the catalytic mechanisms for the two sets of catalysts. TSAC is shown to be viable for selecting the most active esterolytic Zn-catalyst from a mixture of five complexes. Keywords Catalyst selection Transition state analog Affinity chromatography Ester hydrolysis Zinc-diimine catalyst 1 Introduction Catalysts play an essential role by facilitating most useful chemical reactions, be they natural, usually catalyzed by enzymes, or synthetic. Hence, the discovery and improvement of new and more efficient or selective catalysts have immense scientific, economic, health, environmental and societal impacts [1–3]. Typically, the process of catalyst discovery and optimization for a reaction of interest, i.e. finding the most active or selective catalyst, employs a time-consuming, semi-rational, trial-and-error, feedback approach involving: (1) initial selection based on prior precedents and mechanistic concepts (if known); (2) one-at-a-time catalyst preparation; (3) activity/selectivity testing in the reaction of interest; and (4) repetition of (1)–(3). More recently, high throughput parallel, non-rational synthesis/testing approaches have also been developed, which have accelerated the pace of catalyst discovery [4–6]. Transition state theory and its application to enzyme catalysis led to the Pauling-Jencks proposals that a catalyst’s activity is primarily determined by its relative stabilization of the transition state versus the substrate [7,8]. This concept was central to the development of catalytic antibodies [9–11], in which antibodies are raised against a protein-tethered transition state analog (TSA, hapten), and also to the design of imprinted polymer catalysts [12]. In the domain of more rational homogeneous catalyst discovery, solution phase selection based on substrate-, product- or TSA-affinity has been explored in rather few systems [13–15]. Otto, Sanders and coworkers have used product or transition state analogs to amplify and select cycloaddition and acetal hydrolytic organocatalysts from dynamic combinatorial libraries of macrocycles [16,17]. We have shown that the catalytic activity of a small set of hydrolytic Zn(II)-imine complexes correlates with their affinity for esterolytic TSAs [18,19] and we have explored the relationship between cycloadduct-Cu(I)L affinity (‘late’-TSA) and LCu(I)-catalyzed hetero-Diels-Alder regioselectivity [20]. In a complementary approach Reek and coworkers found that the most active palladium complex catalysts for allylic alkylation formed the least stable (least abundant) intermediate allyl-Pd complexes (‘survival of the weakest’) [21]. Introduced here is a new method for homogeneous catalyst selection, which we term transition state affinity chromatography, TSAC. Affinity chromatography has been widely exploited as a qualitative method for protein purification, using either an immobilized affinity ligand, e.g. an enzyme substrate or transition state analog, or an affinity tag on the biomolecule (e.g. His-tag) with a high affinity binding site on the support, e.g. a partially ligated metal center [22,23]. Solid state substrate-receptor affinity has also been used to drive a chemical equilibrium [24]. Affinty chromatography also allows quantification of equilibria between the mobile phase species and the stationary phase binding site based on retention times [25], with application to drug/protein binding assay [26]. In this first evaluation of TSAC as a method for catalyst selection the reversible binding behavior of metal complex pre-catalysts with immobilized-substrate and −transition state analogs is used to assess the complex’s relative affinity for the substrate versus a TSA (Fig. 1 ). According to transition state theory the catalyst that shows the weakest affinity for the substrate-column and the strongest for the TSA-column should be the most active. Specifically, we evaluate here the efficacy of TSAC to select zinc(II) catalysts for picolinate hydrolysis (Scheme 1 ) [27–29], a model reaction with both biochemical (metallo-enzymatic) [30–32] and synthetic metal-ion catalysts [33–35]. Catalysis of these reactions has been suggested to be derived from a combination of coordinative electrophilic activation of the substrate, the enhanced nucleophilicity of coordinated hydroxide and, in some cases, coordinative nucleophilic activation of a neighboring hydroxyalkyl group in the developing tetrahedral intermediate [36,37]. Pseudotetrahedral sulfonamides [38], phosphonates [9,10], dihydroxysilanes [39], boronates [40] and ketone hydrates [41] have been investigated as TSAs for carboxyl hydrolysis and used as inhibitors of esterase and protease enzymes. 2 Results and discussion The complete set of (imine)Zn pre-catalysts was produced by the condensation of six amines and five N-heterocyclic aldehydes to generate bidentate imine ligands, L, 1–30, which with Zn(OTf)2 form thirty LZn(solv)(OTf)+ complexes in Fig. 2 (a),(b). Among these are two groups of ligands in Fig. 2b: sets I, II have nominally inert N-alkyl/aryl side chains and sets III–VI have hydroxy-alkyl side chains, potentially capable of nucleophilic co-catalysis [36,37]. The supported substrate-, transition state analog- and reference- chromatographic materials were prepared as outlined in Scheme 2 , using a variable affinity group and a common linker to condense with commercial aminopropyl-functionalized silica. The substrate affinity support, Sil-Sub, was prepared efficiently in four steps by radical acylation of 4-cyanopyridine with ethyl pyruvate [42], hydrogenation of the nitrile function (85%), acylation of the resulting amine with succinic anhydride (90%), and coupling of acid derivative A with aminopropyl silica (Scheme 2A). The IR spectrum of Sil-Sub showed the disappearance of the carboxyl carbonyl peak at 1720cm−1 of A and the appearance of new strong peaks at 1735 (ester CO) and 1654cm−1 (amide CO). Selectivity issues derived from the installation of the reactive ketone hydrate and amino functions required a longer route to the TSA-supported affinity column Sil-TSA (Scheme 2.B). 4-Cyanopyridine was hydroxymethylated, then oxidized to the corresponding aldehyde [43], which was efficiently converted to the trifluoromethyl alcohol B (96%) by reaction with TMSCF3 (35%, 3 steps). Hydrogenation of the cyano group of B (92%) was followed by amine acylation with succinic anhydride (80%), then SeO2 oxidation to the ketone hydrate C (88%); aminopropyl silica was likewise functionalized with C to give Sil-TSA. The IR spectrum of Sil-TSA showed the disappearance of the 1750cm−1 peak of the ester and the appearance of a strong peak at 1654cm−1 assignable to the amide moieties. Finally, a non-coordinating benzyl reference column Sil-Ref, was prepared to evaluate and compensate for non-specific support- and linker-interactions (Scheme 2C). Reacting benzylamine with succinic anhydride [44] gave the acyl derivative D, which was coupled to aminopropyl-silica. The IR spectrum of Sil-Ref showed disappearance of the carboxyl group at 1720cm−1 and a new amide carbonyl peak at 1658cm−1. The retention times (RTs) of the imine-zinc complexes (Fig. 2) were then determined on each of the affinity columns, employing a Zn(OTf)2 buffer (10−2 M) in 40:60 EtOH/hexane as eluent (Table 1 ). Each of the non-ligand peaks eluting from the Sil-TSA column showed an ESI–MS peak at the M/z corresponding to (L)Zn(OTf)+, (L)Zn(OTf)(MeOH)+ and/or (L)Zn(OTf)(HOTf)+ (MeOH ESI–MS solvent). These chromatographic data reveal: (1) considerable differences in the retention times among the various complexes on the Sil-Ref column, suggestive of varied linker and residual silica-OH surface interactions with the complexes; (2) longer RTs on the Sil-Sub column relative to the Sil-Ref column, indicating substantial coordinating substrate affinity; and (3) generally the longest RTs on the TSA column, suggesting a greater affinity for the gem-diol TSA relative to the substrate ester. The chromatographic retention factors of the complexes, Q, are determined from the retention times (RT) according to the relationships: Qsub =(RTsub −RTref)/(RTref −RTsolv) and QTSA/Qsub =(RTTSA −RTref)/(RTsub −RTref) (see SI). The Q values (Table 1) are proportional to the relative binding affinities of the Zn-complexes for the substrate (vs. reference) and the TSA vs. substrate affinity ligands, respectively. In order to correlate the affinity chromatographic binding properties of the Zn-imine complexes with their catalytic activity, the initial rates of the (L 1-30 )Zn(OTf)-catalyzed hydrolysis of 4-nitrophenyl picolinate were determined in MeOH-CH3CN-H2O-MOPS (pH 7.5, 22°C; Scheme 1) by visible monitoring of absorbance (λ 400nm, 4-nitrophenolate) over time. The data were subjected to a non-linear least squares Michaelis-Menten treatment, yielding the values of KM, 1/KM, Vmax, and kcat shown in Table 2 . The KM and 1/KM values are indicative of strong substrate-catalyst binding (when Sub-Cat binding is rapid and reversible relative to slow conversion to product) [45], as is the case for LZn(Sub) [18,46,47], and cover a moderate seven-fold range. The range of kcat values is approximately four fold and reflects the relatively small structural and electronic variation in the ligand set. How do the chromatographic affinities of the LZn-complexes compare to their substrate binding affinities (1/KM) as estimated from the Michaelis-Menton kinetic data? In Fig. 3 the chromatographic retention factors, Qsub, for the hydroxyalkyl-bearing LZn(OTf)2 complexes (sets III–VI) on the Sil-Sub and Sil-Ref columns (from Table 1) are compared to the approximate substrate affinity (1/KM) determined from the kinetics study (Table 2). A moderately good linear correlation (R=0.71) is observed with this set of complexes. This suggests that for the hydroxyalkyl-bearing LZn complexes the substrate analog column mimics reasonably well the substrate/complex binding as estimated by 1/KM. When all the ligands (1-9/11-30) are included in the Qsub vs. 1/KM plot the correlation is considerably worse (R=0.44; see Fig. SI27), suggesting a difference in the binding mode and affinity for the two different ligands types, I/II vs III–VI. Another factor that may contribute to the scatter and nts in Figs. 3 and 4 is the difference in the solvent composition in the chromatographic (ethanol/hexane) and kinetics experiments (buffered methanol/acetonitrile/H2O), the former being needed to separate the various complexes, while the latter was needed to minimize transesterification and buffer precipitation in the kinetics experiments. We now consider the relationship between the differential TSA-substrate chromatographic affinities (retention factors), QTSA/Qsub, of the complexes (1–30)Zn(OTf)2 and their catalytic activity, kcat. Contrasting behavior between the OH-bearing and non-OH-bearing ligand-Zn complexes is observed here as well. For the hydroxyalkyl-bearing set of complexes (III–VI) a moderately correlated positive linear relationship (R=0.63) is indeed observed (Fig. 4a), as predicted by transition state theory. When the set of complexes from ligand group V containing the Ph-substituted arm is excluded from the plot (Fig. 4a), the correlation between kcat and QTSA/Qsub is even better (R=0.77). This suggests that the TSA- and Sub-affinity chromatography sites model reasonably well the actual reaction substrate and transition state. The observed correlation between TSA- vs Sub-column affinity and kcat is consistent with the principle that the greater the affinity of the catalyst for the transition state relative to the substrate, the lower the activation energy, and the greater its catalytic activity. We speculate that complexes having the Ph-substituted arm may suffer from a steric effect that limits participation of the pendant OH group in nucleophilic co-catalysis. Curiously, for the complexes lacking the OH-pendant ligands, there is a rather good negative linear correlation between QTSA/Qsub and kcat (Fig. 4b); i.e. the most catalytically active complexes of this group have a relatively greater affinity for the Sub-column compared to the TSA-column. These results may indicate that the transition states (and rate-limiting step) for the esterolysis catalyzed by the two sets of complexes differ. Thus, for the OH-bearing L–Zn complexes, the rate-limiting step for hydrolysis could be LZn-OR assisted water attack on the coordinated ester substrate to form the tetrahedral intermediate, whereas for the (non-OHL)Zn catalysts (groups I,II), the RLS could be the collapse of the tetrahedral intermediate to product. [48] As to the catalyst structure/activity relationships revealed by the results, we note that: (1) the most active (largest kcat) catalysts, 9-Zn(OTf)2 and 3-Zn(OTf)2, feature the same length OH-alkyl tether arm and a diimine ligand derived from the less basic aryl amine, but differ in the imidazole (pKa BH+ 6.95) vs. benzimidazole (pKa BH+ 5.4) unit. [49] These complexes have the greatest Lewis acidity and the −OH group poised for Zn-OR coordination, enabling dual electrophilic and nucleophilic catalysis. These are also the complexes correctly selected by TSAC as the best catalysts, having the greatest preferential Sil-TSA/Sil-Sub binding. In contrast, the least active catalysts are those incorporating the more basic diimine ligands, as in 4, 16, 20, and these have the lowest TSA-Sil to Sub-Sil chromatographic relative affinity (QTSA/Qsub) and the largest 1/KM. The practical application of TSAC for catalyst selection would ideally analyze a mixture of complexes avoiding one-at-a-time synthesis/activity testing. We show in Fig. 5 that a mixture of five zinc complexes of ligands 1, 7 (non-OH bearing) and 9, 15, and 27 (OH-bearing) are reasonably well resolved on the three affinity columns. Considering the retention behavior of the structurally related OH-bearing L-Zn compounds (9, 15, and 27), one can see that the complex of 9 shows the greater relative affinity for the TSA vs. the Sub column (QTSA/QSub =1.65 for 9, 1.56 for 15, 1.24 for 27 [50]) and thus would be correctly selected by TSAC as the more active of these three catalysts. Although the peak resolution in the present chromatographic system is limited (ca. 1min), these results provide a proof of concept that TSAC has the potential for high throughput catalyst selection. 3 Conclusions The differential chromatographic retention times of the group of Zn-(imine) complexes bearing hydroxyalkyl arms on designer substrate and transition state affinity columns correlate positively with their substrate binding affinities and catalytic activities for picolinate esterolysis, i.e. the complexes having the greater relative affinity for the transition state versus the substrate columns are the most active catalysts. The correlation between chromatographic and kinetic parameters, however, is much poorer (and even reversed) for the catalysts lacking the co-catalytic hydroxyalkyl side chains. These results reveal a limitation of the TSAC method- it's effectiveness may be limited to libraries of catalysts that operate by a common mechanism and transition state. Put in another way, the TSAC selection method is only as good as the accuracy of the TSA for the reaction's actual transition state. Efforts are planned to enhance the practicality of this new catalyst selection method by improving chromatographic resolution, decreasing the number of affinity columns used, extending the method to other homogeneously catalyzed reactions and demonstrating its use for discovering stereoselective catalysts. 4 Experimental part 4.1 Materials preparation Several heterocyclic aldehydes needed for the preparation of the ligands were prepared by literature methods (see SI for refs and characterizational data). 4.1.1 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde To 50ml of dry THF under argon, 3.48g (20mmol) of the imidazole was added at room temperature. Each column was functionalized by the procedure below with the substrate analog with linker, the benzyl reference with linker or the TSA with linker. After the test, a small portion of the silica gel at both the inlet and the outlet of the column were removed for IR analysis. To make the columns for the chromatography studies, three identical brand new HPLC aminopropyl columns (Zobax NH2 4.5×150mm 5μm, product number 883952-708) were functionalized by the same method (below) but stationary phase samples were not taken for IR analysis. 4.2.1 Drying column Pure nitrogen gas was run through the column at the rate∼1ml/min for 4h then the column oven was turned on to 80°C for 24h. On the next day, the oven was turned off and allowed to cool down to room temperature while the N2 gas was still running. After the oven and column reached room temperature, the N2 gas was shut off. The HPLC line was flushed with THF (dried over Na/benzophenone), then the column was connected and washed with an additional 50ml of dry THF. To prepare the active ester for silica functionalization: 10mmol of either the substrate analog with linker (2.80g), the benzyl reference with linker (2.07g) or the TSA with linker (3.22g) was added to 50ml of dry DMF (Drisolv®). The mixture was stirred until clear and N,N′-diisopropylcarbodiimide (DIC) (12mmol, 1.87ml) and hydroxybenzotriazole (HOBt) (1.62g, 12.0mmol) were added. The mixture was left at room temperature for 2h and the solid was separated by filtration (Millipore® nylon 66); the filtrate solution was used to functionalize the aminopropyl silica. 4.2.2 In-column functionalization The instrument was set up as in the SI. The filtered mixture was pumped at the rate of 1.0ml/min through the column during the reaction. The reaction was set at room temperature for 5h, then the temperature was slowly ramped up to 80°C over 2h and held at 80°C overnight. The next day, the oven was turned off and the column was cooled down to room temperature (HPLC pump still on). The column was subsequently washed with 50ml of DMF, 50ml of dry THF and 100ml of MeOH. During the reaction, if the back pressure rose above 3500 psi, then the pump was stopped for filter cleaning or changing (if needed). The IR analysis of the method validation columns (packed in lab) showed no difference in the spectra of silica removed from the inlet and the outlet ends. The spectra of the amino silica gel before and after the functionalization with the reference, substrate and TSA conjugates are in the SI. 4.2.3 Column equilibration/saturation The columns were washed with 50ml of EtOH then changed into the recirculation mode. A 40 EtOH:60 Hexane mixture (500ml) with 10−2M of Zn(OTf)2 salt as buffer were pumped though the column over 24–48h until the retention times of L9 were unchanged. At this stage, the column is saturated with Zn2+ and ready to use for all chromatographic experiments. 4.2.4 Chromatographic measurements Pre-catalysts were prepared in situ by mixing 1ml (0.1M in EtOH) of each of the constituent aldehyde, amine, and zinc trifluoromethanesulfonate and allowing the mixture to equilibrate at room temperature at least 48h. In each run, 100μl of pre-catalyst solution was injected to overfill the 25μl sample loop. The 40:60 EtOH/hexane mixture with 10−2 M Zn(OTf)2 buffer was used in all chromatographic experiments. The HPLC UV detector was set at either: 375, 325 or 254nm for maximum absorbance. At these wavelengths the molar absorptivity of the aldehyde and amine building blocks are negligible compared to those of the (imine)Zn(OTf)2 complexes. Also, the retention times of the building blocks were significantly shorter than the corresponding (imine)Zn(OTf)2 complexes. For the purpose of further verification, each peak eluted from the TSA bound column and (L9)Zn(OTf)2 eluted from the benzyl reference column and the substrate column were also collected and analyzed by ESI–MS. In all of the cases, at least the M/z of each following complexes corresponding to (imine)Zn(OTf)+, (imine)Zn(OTf)(MeOH)+ or (imine)Zn(OTfO)(OTfH)+ was detected. For the purpose of instrument checking/calibration, (L9)Zn(OTf)2 was used as standard before and after each experiment day. In all of the cases, the variation in retention time of (L9)Zn(OTf)2 was less than 0.1min over 7.1–9.6min of running time giving an estimated uncertainty of ±2% with all of the chromatographic results. Higher throughput chromatographic experiments. Pre-catalysts were prepared by the above method and mixed before the injection in order to limited the ligands exchange. In all of the cases, the time from mixing to injection was no more than 10s. From the observed chromatograms, there is no significant appearance of ligand exchange between the complexes. 4.2.5 Kinetics measurements Zinc complexes of the various ligands were prepared in situ by mixing 0.10mmol each of the constituent aldehyde, amine, and zinc trifluoromethanesulfonate in 25ml methanol and allowing the mixture to equilibrate at room temperature at least 48h. Each of these solutions was then diluted 1:10 to produce 0.40mM solutions for use in the assay. The buffer solution used for the kinetics runs was 100mM MOPS at pH 7.5. The substrate, p-nitrophenyl pyridine carboxylate, was prepared by a literature procedure [7]. The substrate solution at 40mM was prepared in a 10ml volumetric flask using dry acetonitrile (dried and distilled over CaH2) and stored under nitrogen in the freezer when not in use. A new substrate solution was prepared each morning and discarded at the end of the day to minimize background substrate hydrolysis. To convert absorbance values to concentrations a calibration curve was prepared using p-nitrophenol in water with excess KOH to ensure the compound is in the colored (phenolate) form. The concentrations used for the calibration curve were 1.0×10−4 M, 7.5×10−5 M, 5.0×10−5 M, and 2.5×10−5 M. The extinction coefficient was calculated to be 17850M−1. Kinetic measurements were performed in a 1cm quartz cuvette on a diode array spectrophotometer (HP8452A) at ambient temperature (22–24°C). The reaction solutions used in the cuvette were made from 800μl MOPS-H2O, 400μl catalyst solution (MeOH), 500–800μl substrate solution (CH3CN), and acetonitrile added to fill volume for a total of 2ml reaction mixture. The absorbance at 400nm was monitored for 4-nitrophenolate production and the absorbance at 520nm was monitored for variations in the baseline to ensure the data were trustworthy. Samples were taken every 7s for 7min, with minutes 1–3 used for data processing. The data were only kept if the R2 value of the Lineweaver-Burk plot was >0.96; the average R2 for the 29L-Zn complexes tested was 0.98. For the Michaelis-Menten treatment, rates were measured as initial rates with the substrate concentrations of 16mM, 14mM, 12mM, and 10mM in the final mixture and at a low catalyst loading (0.08mM after mixing) with samples taken every 7s and the time from minute 1 to minute 3 used for data processing. Over the course of the observation window, the most substrate that was ever converted was 3×10−5 M, or less than 1% conversion. The KM, Vmax, and kcat were calculated from the absorbance vs. time data (see other SI file). Values for KM and Vmax were obtained by performing a nonlinear least-squares analysis, meaning that a value was calculated for V0 using the tested values for [S] and placeholder values for Vmax and KM, then both Vmax and KM were varied by the Solver plugin for Excel until Σ[(calculated value)-(experimental value)]2 was minimized. Percent uncertainty here was approximated from the average percent difference between calculated values and experimentally determined values. For convenience, since KM is an inverse constant, 1/KM is also provided to compare binding affinities (association constants) more directly. The absorbance vs time and other processed kinetic data are given in the other SI file. Acknowledgements We thank the National Science Foundation for early support of this project (CHE-0911158). We are also grateful to Profs. Richard Taylor, Paul Sims, and Paul Cook for helpful discussions and to Mr. Michael Woodman at HP-Agilent for a generous donation of HPLC columns. Appendix A Supplementary data The supporting information is available free of charge on the journal website. Included are materials preparation and characterizational spectra, and derivation of the relationships between retention factors and kinetic parameters.. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2017.05.014. coredata.dc:description: A new method for catalyst selection-optimization is introduced and evaluated, transition state affinity chromatography (TSAC), based on the relative chromatographic affinity of pre-catalysts for a supported-substrate vs. a transition state analog (TSA). The affinities of a library of Zn-imine complexes on three designer HPLC affinity columns that possess either an immobilized substrate, a transition state analog or a non-binding reference compound are compared to their catalytic activities for picolinate ester hydrolysis. For those Zn-complexes whose ligands possess a hydroxyalkyl side chain the retention times on the substrate-affinity column correlate linearly with the catalyst-substrate affinity, 1/KM, derived from the kinetics of the LZn-catalyzed hydrolysis of 4-nitrophenyl picolinate. Additionally, the kinetically determined esterolytic catalytic activities, kcat, for the hydroxyalkyl-bearing complexes also correlate with their relative chromatographic affinity on the TSA- vs Sub-affinity columns. Zinc-complexes that lack the hydroxyalkyl arm, however, show no correlation of their chromatographic behavior with 1/KM and an inverse correlation with kcat. These results are interpreted in terms of differences in the catalytic mechanisms for the two sets of catalysts. TSAC is shown to be viable for selecting the most active esterolytic Zn-catalyst from a mixture of five complexes.
coredata.dc:title: Catalyst selection by transition state affinity chromatography—An assessment
